topics.body:
Speaking of black holes here's some cool science stuff; this is how a supernova actually looks:
"star collapse":https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2RxIwtxdEnQ
We're talking about it happening in less than a second too.  If you think a star dying is some peaceful event you're totally wrong.

Even though the sun isn't going to die for a billion years and chances are with how small our sun is it would just become a brown dwarf, if it were to go supernova we would have no warning cause the supernova would travel at near light speed and by the time the light reaches you would have less than one second before the blast.

topics.body: IDK what's going on but it looks like the New Lunar Republic facebook group has been hacked. Some tard is converting it into a Solar Empire group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/636907726354418/

"@Princess♠Molestia":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/554fc9366368727f403e0a00#post_554fc9366368727f403e0a00
[bq="Princess♠Molestia"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/554fc8636368727f40370900#post_554fc8636368727f40370900
So basically when it happens the solar system gets flattened immediately?[/bq]
Literally at the speed of light.

We don't have to worry about our sun going supernova though.  What we do have to worry about is a local star a couple light years from us going supernova though.  If a star close to us were to go supernova it would usher in a severe ice age.  Considering the stars that are close to us the worst case scenario is a ice age.



What we do have to worry about is that in certain parts of the galaxy there's large amounts of dust.  You know how the asteroid field is mainly just insanely large dust clusters?  Imagine how large the dust cluster for the milk way is?  If the earth were to come in contact with one of these dust clusters we would be done for and would *HAVE* to move to space.  Imagine a metric meter of dust collecting on the earth monthly on average. . . I don't mean that as total; rather I mean at the end of the month the dust would be a meter deep; next month it would be another meter deep and it would continue for thousands of years of continuously collecting that much dust.

We probably don't have to worry about this one though, cause it's never happened to the earth previously; if it did happen simply put life on earth would be extinct.

topics.body:
"@QuasarNova":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/554fc9f26368727f400a0b00#post_554fc9f26368727f400a0b00
[bq="QuasarNova"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/554fc8636368727f40370900#post_554fc8636368727f40370900

Pretty sure this is a dumb question but is the theory that neutrinos could mitigate the shockwave somewhat?[/bq]
No; when a star collapses the forces to keep the star intact are no longer strong enough to counteract the forces that pull it apart.  We don't have to worry about our sun going supernova though; it will just become a brown dwarf.  However what we would have to worry about is when it starts dying before it becomes a brown dwarf it will expand and eventually swallow the earth and then it will shrink.

topics.body:
"@Princess♠Molestia":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/554fcc2a6368727f408b0d00#post_554fcc2a6368727f408b0d00
There's a theory that the reason why we haven't found alien life yet is that space is very very very hostile place and that most life gets destroyed before it evolves sapience.

We probably will find alien life in our own solar system, probably Europa, but we're talking about only bacteria or such cause the conditions for sapience to arise are really fickle.

When we eventually do start colonizing Mars or such there's a pretty good chances that we might find fossils of some form of life, but keep in mind that mars is constantly getting pounded with radiation cause it doesn't have a magnetic field.

If there is sapient advanced alien life then we're talking about them being conservatively thousands of light years apart.


Let's assume that there's say the Daleks out there and they want to wipe out all life; the amount of distance between them and the next civilization would be so distant that it would just be unfeasible to do so.  There probably is hundreds of thousands of advanced species in the galaxy, but chances are they are so far apart from each other that it would take thousands of years to get to each other.

From out current understanding of physics faster than light travel is impossible or if someone actually does it then they would have be one of the most advanced species in the galaxy.

What I mean by all this is that A)space is very fucking hostile B)the earth is lucky C)if there is alien life out there chances are they're so far away that it would take thousands of years to get to them D)only the most advanced of advanced species would be capable of faster than light travel.

Tl:dr; bacteria and such is probably common in the galaxy; sapience is probably rare cause of how long it takes to evolve and that most life gets wiped out before it can evolve into sapient species cause of how hostile space is.
